trans-unit.source: How to use Queue storage from .NET | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: How to use Queue storage from .NET | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Learn how to use Microsoft Azure Queue storage to create and delete queues and insert, peek, get, and delete queue messages.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to use Microsoft Azure Queue storage to create and delete queues and insert, peek, get, and delete queue messages.

trans-unit.source: This guide will show you how to perform common scenarios using the Azure Queue storage service.
trans-unit.target: This guide will show you how to perform common scenarios using the Azure Queue storage service.

trans-unit.source: The samples are written in C\# code and use the Azure Storage Client for .NET.
trans-unit.target: The samples are written in C\# code and use the Azure Storage Client for .NET.

trans-unit.source: The scenarios covered include inserting, peeking, getting, and deleting queue messages, as well as creating and deleting queues.
trans-unit.target: The scenarios covered include inserting, peeking, getting, and deleting queue messages, as well as creating and deleting queues.

trans-unit.source: Add the following code namespace declarations to the top of any C\# file in which you wish to programmatically access Azure Storage:
trans-unit.target: Add the following code namespace declarations to the top of any C\# file in which you wish to programmatically access Azure Storage:

trans-unit.source: Make sure you reference the Microsoft.WindowsAzure.Storage.dll assembly.
trans-unit.target: Make sure you reference the Microsoft.WindowsAzure.Storage.dll assembly.

trans-unit.source: A CloudQueueClient object lets you get reference objects for queues.
trans-unit.target: A CloudQueueClient object lets you get reference objects for queues.

trans-unit.source: The following code creates a CloudQueueClient object.
trans-unit.target: The following code creates a CloudQueueClient object.

trans-unit.source: All code in this guide uses a storage connection string stored in the Azure application's service configuration.
trans-unit.target: All code in this guide uses a storage connection string stored in the Azure application's service configuration.

trans-unit.source: There are also other ways to create a CloudStorageAccount object.
trans-unit.target: There are also other ways to create a CloudStorageAccount object.

trans-unit.source: See <linkText>CloudStorageAccount</linkText><title></title> documentation for details.
trans-unit.target: See <linkText>CloudStorageAccount</linkText><title></title> documentation for details.

trans-unit.source: Use the queueClient object to get a reference to the queue you want to use.
trans-unit.target: Use the queueClient object to get a reference to the queue you want to use.

trans-unit.source: You can create the queue if it doesn't exist.
trans-unit.target: You can create the queue if it doesn't exist.

trans-unit.source: To insert a message into an existing queue, first create a new CloudQueueMessage.
trans-unit.target: To insert a message into an existing queue, first create a new CloudQueueMessage.

trans-unit.source: Next, call the AddMessage method.
trans-unit.target: Next, call the AddMessage method.

trans-unit.source: A CloudQueueMessage can be created from either a string (in UTF-8 format) or a byte array.
trans-unit.target: A CloudQueueMessage can be created from either a string (in UTF-8 format) or a byte array.

trans-unit.source: Here is code which creates a queue (if it doesn't exist) and inserts the message 'Hello, World':
trans-unit.target: Here is code which creates a queue (if it doesn't exist) and inserts the message 'Hello, World':

trans-unit.source: You can peek at the message in the front of a queue without removing it from the queue by calling the PeekMessage method.
trans-unit.target: You can peek at the message in the front of a queue without removing it from the queue by calling the PeekMessage method.

trans-unit.source: You can change the contents of a message in-place in the queue.
trans-unit.target: You can change the contents of a message in-place in the queue.

trans-unit.source: If the message represents a work task, you could use this feature to update the status of the work task.
trans-unit.target: If the message represents a work task, you could use this feature to update the status of the work task.

trans-unit.source: The following code updates the queue message with new contents, and sets the visibility timeout to extend another 60 seconds.
trans-unit.target: The following code updates the queue message with new contents, and sets the visibility timeout to extend another 60 seconds.

trans-unit.source: This saves the state of work associated with the message, and gives the client another minute to continue working on the message.
trans-unit.target: This saves the state of work associated with the message, and gives the client another minute to continue working on the message.

trans-unit.source: You could use this technique to track multi-step workflows on queue messages, without having to start over from the beginning if a processing step fails due to hardware or software failure.
trans-unit.target: You could use this technique to track multi-step workflows on queue messages, without having to start over from the beginning if a processing step fails due to hardware or software failure.

trans-unit.source: Typically, you would keep a retry count as well, and if the message is retried more than n times, you would delete it.
trans-unit.target: Typically, you would keep a retry count as well, and if the message is retried more than n times, you would delete it.

trans-unit.source: This protects against a message that triggers an application error each time it is processed.
trans-unit.target: This protects against a message that triggers an application error each time it is processed.

trans-unit.source: Your code de-queues a message from a queue in two steps.
trans-unit.target: Your code de-queues a message from a queue in two steps.

trans-unit.source: When you call GetMessage, you get the next message in a queue.
trans-unit.target: When you call GetMessage, you get the next message in a queue.

trans-unit.source: A message returned from GetMessage becomes invisible to any other code reading messages from this queue.
trans-unit.target: A message returned from GetMessage becomes invisible to any other code reading messages from this queue.

trans-unit.source: By default, this message stays invisible for 30 seconds.
trans-unit.target: By default, this message stays invisible for 30 seconds.

trans-unit.source: To finish removing the message from the queue, you must also call DeleteMessage.
trans-unit.target: To finish removing the message from the queue, you must also call DeleteMessage.

trans-unit.source: This two-step process of removing a message assures that if your code fails to process a message due to hardware or software failure, another instance of your code can get the same message and try again.
trans-unit.target: This two-step process of removing a message assures that if your code fails to process a message due to hardware or software failure, another instance of your code can get the same message and try again.

trans-unit.source: Your code calls DeleteMessage right after the message has been processed.
trans-unit.target: Your code calls DeleteMessage right after the message has been processed.

trans-unit.source: This example shows how to use the Async-Await pattern with common Queue storage APIs.
trans-unit.target: This example shows how to use the Async-Await pattern with common Queue storage APIs.

trans-unit.source: The sample calls the asynchronous version of each of the given methods, as indicated by the Async suffix of each method.
trans-unit.target: The sample calls the asynchronous version of each of the given methods, as indicated by the Async suffix of each method.

trans-unit.source: When an async method is used, the async-await pattern suspends local execution until the call completes.
trans-unit.target: When an async method is used, the async-await pattern suspends local execution until the call completes.

trans-unit.source: This behavior allows the current thread to do other work, which helps avoid performance bottlenecks and improves the overall responsiveness of your application.
trans-unit.target: This behavior allows the current thread to do other work, which helps avoid performance bottlenecks and improves the overall responsiveness of your application.

trans-unit.source: For more details on using the Async-Await pattern in .NET see <linkText>Async and Await (C# and Visual Basic)</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: For more details on using the Async-Await pattern in .NET see <linkText>Async and Await (C# and Visual Basic)</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: There are two ways you can customize message retrieval from a queue.
trans-unit.target: There are two ways you can customize message retrieval from a queue.

trans-unit.source: First, you can get a batch of messages (up to 32).
trans-unit.target: First, you can get a batch of messages (up to 32).

trans-unit.source: Second, you can set a longer or shorter invisibility timeout, allowing your code more or less time to fully process each message.
trans-unit.target: Second, you can set a longer or shorter invisibility timeout, allowing your code more or less time to fully process each message.

trans-unit.source: The following code example uses the GetMessages method to get 20 messages in one call.
trans-unit.target: The following code example uses the GetMessages method to get 20 messages in one call.

trans-unit.source: Then it processes each message using a foreach loop.
trans-unit.target: Then it processes each message using a foreach loop.

trans-unit.source: It also sets the invisibility timeout to five minutes for each message.
trans-unit.target: It also sets the invisibility timeout to five minutes for each message.

trans-unit.source: Note that the 5 minutes starts for all messages at the same time, so after 5 minutes have passed since the call to GetMessages, any messages which have not been deleted will become visible again.
trans-unit.target: Note that the 5 minutes starts for all messages at the same time, so after 5 minutes have passed since the call to GetMessages, any messages which have not been deleted will become visible again.

trans-unit.source: You can get an estimate of the number of messages in a queue.
trans-unit.target: You can get an estimate of the number of messages in a queue.

trans-unit.source: The FetchAttributes method asks the Queue service to retrieve the queue attributes, including the message count.
trans-unit.target: The FetchAttributes method asks the Queue service to retrieve the queue attributes, including the message count.

trans-unit.source: The ApproximateMethodCount property returns the last value retrieved by the FetchAttributes method, without calling the Queue service.
trans-unit.target: The ApproximateMethodCount property returns the last value retrieved by the FetchAttributes method, without calling the Queue service.

trans-unit.source: To delete a queue and all the messages contained in it, call the Delete method on the queue object.
trans-unit.target: To delete a queue and all the messages contained in it, call the Delete method on the queue object.

trans-unit.source: Now that you've learned the basics of Queue storage, follow these links to learn about more complex storage tasks.
trans-unit.target: Now that you've learned the basics of Queue storage, follow these links to learn about more complex storage tasks.

trans-unit.source: View the Queue service reference documentation for complete details about available APIs:
trans-unit.target: View the Queue service reference documentation for complete details about available APIs:

trans-unit.target: <linkText>Storage Client Library for .NET reference</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.target: <linkText>REST API reference</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: Learn about more advanced tasks you can perform with Azure Storage at <linkText>Storing and Accessing Data in Azure</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: Learn about more advanced tasks you can perform with Azure Storage at <linkText>Storing and Accessing Data in Azure</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: Learn how to simplify the code you write to work with Azure Storage by using the <linkText>Azure WebJobs SDK</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to simplify the code you write to work with Azure Storage by using the <linkText>Azure WebJobs SDK</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: View more feature guides to learn about additional options for storing data in Azure.
trans-unit.target: View more feature guides to learn about additional options for storing data in Azure.

trans-unit.source: Use <linkText>Table Storage</linkText><title></title> to store structured data.
trans-unit.target: Use <linkText>Table Storage</linkText><title></title> to store structured data.

trans-unit.source: Use <linkText>Blob Storage</linkText><title></title> to store unstructured data.
trans-unit.target: Use <linkText>Blob Storage</linkText><title></title> to store unstructured data.

trans-unit.source: Use <linkText>SQL Database</linkText><title></title> to store relational data.
trans-unit.target: Use <linkText>SQL Database</linkText><title></title> to store relational data.
